'''Arathorn I''' was the twelfth [[Chieftain of the Dúnedain]].<ref name=Arathorn/>

== History ==
In the days of his father, [[Arassuil]], the [[Orcs of the Misty Mountains]] emerged again.<ref>{{App|Eriador}}, ''The North-kingdom and the Dúnedain'', p. 1043</ref> Arathorn succeeded Arassuil, on his death in {{TA|2784|n}}.<ref name=Arassuil/>

Arathorn died prematurely<ref group=note>This is deduced from the dagger symbol (†) next to his year of death and the explanation of the meaning of this symbol in the introduction to ''[[Appendix A]]''.</ref> in {{TA|2848|n}}.<ref name=Arathorn/> He was succeeded by his son [[Argonui]].<ref>{{App|North}}, ''Chieftains'', Argonui, p. 1038</ref>

== Etymology ==
{{Pronounce|Arathorn.mp3|Ardamir}}
The etymology of the name ''Arathorn'' is uncertain. See [[Arathorn II#Etymology|Arathorn II - Etymology]] for discussion.

== Other versions of the legendarium ==
Arathorn I's year of birth is only mentioned in earlier manuscript versions of what would later become Appendix A. In general, J.R.R. Tolkien did not include the year of birth of kings and rulers in Appendix A or Appendix B.

In the later manuscript C Arathorn's years of birth and death were {{TA|2693}} and {{TA|2848|n}}, respectively.<ref name=ManuscriptC>{{PM|Elendil}}, ''End of the North Kingdom'', 37. 12. Arathorn I, p. 196</ref> In the same manuscript it is also mentioned that [[Dírhael]], the maternal grandfather of [[Aragorn]], was descended from Arathorn I "by a younger branch".<ref>{{PM|Elendil}}, ''End of the North Kingdom'', 40. 15. Arathorn II, p. 196</ref>

In the earlier manuscript B, the years of Arathorn I's birth and death were {{TA|2683}} and {{TA|2838|n}}, respectively.<ref>{{PM|Elendil}}, ''Commentary'', Arathorn I, pp. 210-11</ref>
